To detract from my Siſter, she is good.
And verie innocent, but her fault is
She cannot hould her peace.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Continue, Brother,
I'm much oblig'd unto you, pray, proceed.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Las! I've ſaid too much,
Excuſe the feares and weaknes of a Lover?
If thy heart felt ſuch ſeiſures thou shouldſt know
That the God, who is Preſident of love,
Is but a timourous child, and trembles alwaies:

sp.speaker: Iſabella
sp.l: I doe confeſſe, that I am ignorant
In maximes of this nature, and indead
Too innocent to underſtand them well:
Concerning your aboad, which I have learn'd
With ſome regrett, for being knowne to me
T'is not leſſe ſecret: I will make appeare
By ſilence and diſcretion, that I am
A better Siſter to you then you are a
Brother to me.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Oh! Siſter, what ſweet ſentiments have you?
How shall I merit them?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: I heare ſome body,
Brother, let us withdraw.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: I'le take your counſell; goe forth of this dwelling
To Carlos houſe, I'le follow you immediatelie.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: YOu ſee Climene ſtayes heere, as I ſaid,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Conduct her! tis ynough, Im ſatisfi'd,
And will goe forth content.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Madame, tis Carlos,
Follow me without feare, ſpeake ſoft —

sp.speaker: Iſabella
sp.l: Tis Carlos,
I'le follow him without conſtraint. — aſide.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Guards, waite upon Climene for this night,
My eyes muſt be deprived of the happines
To ſee her, my love urgeth me in vaine
To follow her, defer we till to morron
To render her a viſſit, the good which
I expect thence would be too dearelie bought
If it should coſt a trouble to Climene.
Depart we, and lets flatter us with hope
That we through perſeverance shall o'rcome,
And that there is no heart ſo hard by charme,
Which thoſe fires in my boſom cannot warme.

div.head: SCENA NONA.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven! what heare I?
My judgment is confounded heere; Climene
Is gone with Carlos, yet ſome ſecret charme
Which I can't comprehend, houldeth her heere
In conference with the shadow of the dead.

sp.speaker: Climene.
sp.l: Everie one is retir'd we are alone,
The Duke is alſo gone out of the garden:
Let's finish the deſigne we have in hand,
Let's preſſe it on, and fly we without feare
That Tyrants love, for whom I've ſo much horrour

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In what a hideous gulfe of black deſpaire
Am I plunged by this prodegy? iſt a truth,
Or iſt a dreame?

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Haſte we, but I'm afrayd
That in the dark we shall not finde the Mine.

sp.speaker: Climene.
sp.l: No matter we caan goe out of the garden
Another way, the key of the back dore
Which I have heere about me privately,
Will give us paſſage forth to Carlos houſe,
Where' gainſt the light returnes, I will be readie
T'embrace thy fortune, and to follow thee,
Goe where thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Climene,
sp.l: Tis ynough, make me no reply, but follow,
We Ioſe time,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There's no doubt of it, tis certaine,
Fabritio either dead of living ſteale
Away Climene; ha! I cannot ſuffer,
This outrage in my ſight: come, I'm reſolv'd
To loſe my ſelfe, or reſkue her; O Heavens!
sp.stage: The Duke running to ſuccour Climene, falles into the Mine.

div.trailer: The End of the fourth Act.

div.head: SCENA PRIMA.
div.stage: In a hall of Carlos houſe.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: WHom ſee I here? misfot tune! oh unluckie
Encounter! but, perhaps, I am deceiv'd,
Is it you, Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Strang? What heare I?
Iſt poſſible that Carlos should not know me?
Are all my features ſuddenlie defaced?
No, they remaine yet, onelie I have cauſe
To thinke ahat they are raz'd out of thy memorie

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Oh, Madame, this ſuſpition is unjuſt,
I will upon this point tell you the truth
With all ſinceritic.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Pray, What ſinceritie
Can one expect from you?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Condemne me not
Before you heare me: I had a deſigne
Which prospered not, my intent was to bring
Another woman here, and I confeſſe
That I am ſorrie now to ſee you Madame.
In her place, your faire preſence is indead
A trouble at this time. But —

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: It ſufficeth,
Ingratefull, thy crime is acknowledged,
And more ſincerely then I could have thought

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Suffer me to expreſſe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: It needs not,
What explication can be more cleer?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: No, I will heare no more,
All thy diſguiſements are ſuperfluous.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: What should I know more? haſt thou not
Tould me that thy ſoule's fleeting, thou intende'ſt
To bring another Woman here, thou wilt
That I believe it, and I doe believe it.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: True, thou haſt not any thing
For me but coldnes, and preſumption;
To ſee me in her place, thou ſayſt, th'art ſorrie,
And with an unjuſt paſſion thy ſalfe ſpirit
Carried away, goes from inconſtancie
To incivilitie.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: What canſt thou ſay unto me?
That thou acknowledgeſt the Empire of
A Worthier object, that in vaine thy heart
Hath ſtood againſt her charmes, and that to gaine thee
I have too little beautie?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Oh deceive not
Your ſelfe with ſo much art, and I beſeech you
Be leſſe unjuſt to my poore heart that loves you.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: In loſing ſuch a heart as thine, I shall
Loſe little, it is faithles, baſe, and treacherous,
And I pretend not any thing unto it;
Adiew.

sp.speaker: Carlos
sp.l: What without hearing me, oh ſtay,
I doe beſeech you, ſtay.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: My preſence here
Doth trouble you.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: A reall truth,
Ingratefull?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: You shall not goe forth before
Y'ave heard me, ſuffer me upon this point
T'ex preſſe my thought.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: I should againe be troubled
With thy diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: What I shall ſay unto you
Can eaſilie be verified.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: No, no,
I forbid thee to juſtifie thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: For the laſt time yet give me leave to ſay,
That it is you alone whom I adore,
That I am wholy yours.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Well, let me ſee then,
If I have any power yet in thy ſoul.

sp.speaker: Carlos
sp.p: Madame, commaund, you shall be ſatiſfied.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Say nothing more then to excuſe thy ſelfe,
And leave me to depart. this I command,
Obey me in this point.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: For ſuch a perfect Lover as I am,
It is a crime t'obey too readilie.

sp.speaker: Iſabella
sp.l: No, no, I have ſome power upon thy ſpirit,
Shew thy reſpect by thy obedience,

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Love by reſpect is verie ill expreſſ'd,
Who can obey well, knoweth not to love,
This favourable councell, cruell Beautie,
Was given to Carlos.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Yes to Carlos faithfull,
But this fatall adviſe, whereof thou doſt
Preſume ſo much, was never given vnto
Carlos inconſtant,

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Ingratefull, I will tell it thee, tis true
I had for thee ſomething about my heart
That ſavoured of tendernes and that
I know not what began to differ little
From the toy called Love; at laſt I was
Tainted with that diſeaſe, when for my punishmēt
I knew my love produeed but thy hate;
True, thou feel'ſt it no more, now that thou ſeeſt
That I am touch'd; I become trouble ſome
To him that's deare to me; now that my flame
Appeares, thine is conſumed, and beginning
To love, I ceaſe to be belov'd. Belov'd?
what have I ſaid'? I learne by the effects,
That thou feigneſt alwaies, and did'ſt never love me
What canſt thou anſweare to excuſe thy ſelfe.
So juſt a reproach cannot but confound thee;
Thou ſtriv'ſt not more to juſtifie thy ſelfe,
Thy ſilence ſpeaks thee guilty and confounded.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: This trouble which appeareth in my countenance
Proceeds from your injuſtice, not my crime.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: What have I ſaid here which thou canſt deny?
Defend thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: You have forbidden me
To juſtifie my ſelfe. I feare you would be
Offended ſtill with my diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: No, no
Speak, Carlos, now my anger's vanished;
Although thou shouldſt be falſe, and prove inconſtant.
In ſuch a high degree as to betray me,
I might cōplaine thereof, but could not hate thee
And whatſoever change thy heart should make.
I should excuſe thee if thou didſt deſire it.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Vpon your faire hands for this ſweet expreſſion,
Let me imprint my joy, and my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: But Madame, your ſuſpitions
Injute my love extremelie.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: My ſuſpitions
Give Carlos intimation that I love him.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: I muſt diſpoſe my ſelfe to dye, he'll kill me — aſide
Father.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Vnworthy object of my anger
In ſtly provoked, I'm thy enemie,
Call me no more thy Father: how! preſum'ſt thou
T'offend me in fo high degree as thus
Againſt the rules of reaſon and of honour
To come to Carlos at his houſe by night,
And in deſpiſing the Religious Cloyſter
Whereto I've deſtin'd thee, to give thy ſelfe
Over to baſe amours?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: I doe beſeech you,
Heare me, graunt me that ſavour, will you, Sir
Refuſe me?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Heare equitic oppreſſed by my mouth,
If her flame be a crime, I m guilty onelie;
Yes if it be a fault, daigne to remember,
That I am the cauſe on't, and whom you ought
Onelie to punish, be more juſt without
Being more gentle, ſave the innocent.
And deſtroy the offender.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: No, againſt me
Bend all your furie, if it be a crime
To love, it is a vertue to be loved:
The tendernes which I reſent for Carlos
Denotes his merit, and ſetts forth my weaknes:
And if my paſſion be worthy death,
Carlos is free, and I alone am guilty.

sp.speaker: Carlos
sp.l: Oh, abandon
That thought.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Then Carlos with my honour take
Away my life, that is the onely way
To make her crime ſafe; nothing but my death
Can ſtop her punishment.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Feare nothing from me,
I have reſpect for you, and ſince I could not
Appeaſe your anger. I oppoſe no further
But rather preſſe you now that Iſabella
May perish

sp.speaker: Iſabella
sp.l: How? doe you preſſe my deſtruction?
Oh now's the fatall moment, wherein I
Have juſt cauſe to complaine of deſtiniie
My heart is peirc'd with griefe to ſee you here
With ſuch injuſtice to become my judge,
And not my complice. I was well reſolv'd,
Carlos, to dye, and quarrell'd not with fate,
So long as I thought to expire for thee;
But I believed not in this adventure
That Love aſwell as Nature would betray me,
And that I should at laſt goe to the grave
Thus by a Fathers ſtroak, and Lovers ſentence.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Madame, I've ſayd but what I should have ſayd:
Once more I doe repeate it, ſince your daughter
Muſt dye, Sir, and I cannot hinder it,
Content your ſelfe to ſtrike, but pray miſtake not
The boſome, heere direct your ſtroaks, tis heere
That Iſabella's lodg'd, heere she is Miſtreſſe,
Heere she is criminall, heere you muſt aſſault her
To punish her, and in peircing my heart,
You cannot miſſe her.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: Oh, believe him not;
Turne your armes here.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Readie to shed my blood,
I feel my teares flow, and my choler's cold:
I onelie by a ſudden ſtrange effect
Am vanquish'd in the fight, let us feigne yet,
Carlos, your cunning for a little time
Retards her Puniſhment, but fatisfy me
Vpon a thing that brought me heere, and wick
Doth trouble me extreemely tell me truelie,
Is my Sonne here, or no; if he be here,
His death is but too certaine.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: I aſſure you,
He is not here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Since you doe aſſure me,
I will not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: WE are free at laſt
From the Dukes hands.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: O Heaven! iſt poſſible?
Fabritio yet preſent him to mine eyes?
I gave, Sir, too much credit to your words. — to Carlos,

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: He was not here, Sir, when I ſaid them to you,

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Thou blinded Sonne, through what ingratitude
Build'ſt thou thy pleaſures upon my diſquiet?
VVhat hath made thee deſpiſe a Fathers Will,
whom thou know'ſt cherisheth thy life ſo much
And why in violating all the rights
Of nature, doſt thou make ſo ſmall accompt
Of the light which thou oweſt me? Ingratefull?

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: The care, Sir, of my ſafetie troubleeh you
Too much, I doe not hate the light, but love is
Leſſe then Climene.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: I commanded thee
To quit this reſidence.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: But I receiv'd
Another order.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Love makes no lawes but for thoſe that will take 'em;
And reaſon now forbiddeth thee to embrace it

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Oh reaſon, Sir, had left me, and I was
Too much enchained, to depart.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Canſt thou
Stay without shame, after an infidelitie?

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Climene is as conſtant as she's faire:
My ſpirit was ſtruck with an injuſt ſuſpition,
I'm diſabuſed, and she's readie heere
To follow me.

sp.speaker: Climene.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
To follow him, I have engag'd my ſelfe;
Though his condition be chang'd, I am not.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: I alwaies doubted till this very moment.
Whether a woman could love conſtantly;
But if your love hath any reaſon with it,
Haſte you to goe out of his fatall cuntry.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: There's nothing that shall ſtop my ſtepps to morrow
Sir, I ſweare to you. —

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: If you believe it not, I doe aſſure you,
You are in an extreme errour; who can ſtay us?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Yes, I will
Tell you a ſad adventure, which should be
Equallie grievous to us both; Climene
Is by a fatall chaunce committed to
My guard, and I'm reſponſible for her.
I've the Dukes order for it, and to add
To the misfortune, I thought to have taken
Climene, and I took your ſiſter for her.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.l: What! this was then the cauſe which troubled you
So much but now?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: You have but little reaſon
To doubt of it; but underſtand my trouble
In this extremitie, if Climene flyes,
I shall be forc'd to expoſe Iſabella
Inſtead of her to the Dukes paſſions:
I love her, and tis now no longer time
To diſguiſe my thoughts to you, Iudge, I pray you,
If in this daunger I ought to expoſe her.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Not ſo great
As it appeares unto you; to be free
Of all ſcare, get ye gone all foure togeither.
The Duke will be reduced afterward
To be appeas'd.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: This is a moſt ſure way;
But whence proceeds this noiſe?

div.head: SCENA QUARTA.
div.stage: Celin, Alphonſo, Carlos, Fabritio, Climeno, Iſabella, Celin to Carlos.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.l: Sir, diverſe men
Armed with halberds deſire ſpeech with you.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: Tis the Duke and his Guards, ſure, their deſigne
Surpriſeth me.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: I have loſt all my hope.
Carlos, aſſuredly my ſonne's diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Carlos
sp.l: We will be preſently cleer'd on that point.
Without light let Fabritio ſtay heere,
And if he doubts that they are come to ſeek him
Behind this falſe wall he may hide himſelfe:
sp.stage: He shewes them a wall which is turn'd upon a pivot of Iron.
sp.l: See, how it turnes; before his death my Father
Fearing the malice of his enemies,
Cauſed it to be made in ſecret for him,
And I know that there is no wit ſo ſubtle,
That can finde out Fabritio in this place.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.p: To ſave thy life, doe this, Sonne, I conjure thee;

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: I obey
As ſonne, and I obey no leſſe as Lover.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Let's ceaſe diſcourſe, and goe forth preſently.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Heaven! muſt I alwaies be diſtracted thus
Twixt feare and hope, and muſt ſo juſt a love
Have ſuch a rigid fortune? the Duke loves,
Or abhorres her, and I know that there's reaſon
To feare all things from him that hopeth nothing;
And that? bove all things it is daungerous
To be competitor with his Prince, and Rivall
Vnto his Maſter. But what • heare I not
Some perſon walke, at if he would come to me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I've paſſed through a ſtreight way, now I enter
Into a greater, yet am ſtill in doubt,
My hope's confounded, and my ſpirits dark,
Which should light me in theſe obſcurities?
Am I'mongſt mortalls? am I in ſome cave?
Am I upon the earth, or in is center?
Murthered Fabritio offereth himſelfe
To my remembrance, would Heaven punish me
For his unjuſt death? but I heare a noyſe,
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Duke.

l.hi: Fabritio!

sp.l: Appeares his Fantaſme heere then for my punishment,
And am I ſunk downe into Hell alive
To ſuffer for the evills I've made him ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: I heare the Dukes voice, which I know full well.
Is it you then, Sir Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Th' art not deceiv'd.
I am the authour of thy death, I will not
Say any thing unto thee for to ſave
My life, thou canſt without crime take it frō him
Who hath tane thine from thee, all the feare which
Reſteth unto me in this ſad misfortune,
Proceedeth from my crime, not from my death;
And if now any griefe oppreſſeth me,
Tis not to dye, but to dye culpable.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: He thinks me ſtill dead, I will profit by
This errour. — aſide.
Duke, you have juſt cauſe to feare
My furie, your fate now is in my power,
Nothing can ſtop the courſe of my revenge;
I can now ſacrifice your blood to mine;
But, Sit, you are my Prince, and I le not doe it;
Injuſtice I abhorre, and notwithſtanding
My anger, I would rather ſuffer it
Then execute it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The mote thy reſpect
Appeares for me, the more unjuſt's thy death
And the more black my crime; by this, my fault
Becomes doubly condemnable, the leſſe
Sevete thou art in punishing me, the more
I'm worthy punishment. But if thy shadow
Pretendeth to reſpect me, what obligeth thee
To perſecute me thus in everie place?
How comes it that thou doſt conferre upon me
Imperfect favouts? why doſt thou purſue me?
What iſt thou doſt deſire?

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Since you ordaine it
I'le ſpeake it then; know, Sir, that this your trouble
Shall never ſee an end before you ceaſe,
To love Climene.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ceaſe to love Climene?
Oh! that's too much preſumption, I may ceaſe
To live, but not to love her, to obtaine
Thy wishes, thou shouldſt ask a poſſible thing;
But I should have abus'd thee if I had
Flattered thy hope that I would ceaſe to love
That charming Beautie.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: To love in this manner
Is to love like a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, I know
That I love like a tyrant, but no matter:
Know alſo that. Love who gives Law to me,
Is yet a blinder tyrant farre then I:
To force me to love this ingratefull Miſtreſſe,
He hath to much ſtrength, and I soo much weaknes
Onelie the hope that I can give thee is,
Never to ſee her more, yet ſtill to love her.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: He that can loſe the object, can loſe alſo
The flame, the heart houlds not what the eye is
Depriv'd of, Love from our will hath his power;
To ceaſe to love, there needs but the deſire:
To put out all your flames, quench all your hope,
And yeild Climene to my conſtancie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But if I should doe ſo, what's thy deſigne?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: To marrie her? what! art thou
Not dead then?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou shouldſt be
O'th' number of the living for this works;
Who cherisheth a body, muſt not be
A shadow. Speak, and believe that thy death
Hath coſt me teares.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: He feigneth for to knowe me,
And to deſtroy me afterward. — aſide.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He anſweareth not a word; Lets ſeek about.
But leaſt he should goe forth, 'tis requiſite
To keepe this porte: to know too where I am,
Tis beſt to make a noyſe; hola! who's there?
Some one come to me.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Heaven! whereto am I
Reduc'd? but let me, ere they bring a light
Advaunce to wards the wall, and hide my ſelfe
Behind it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'le be cleered in this doubt,
Heere comes a light.

div.head: SCENA SEXTA.
div.stage: The Duke, Carlos, Alphonſo, Valerio, Climene, Iſabella, Guards.

sp.speaker: Climene.
sp.p: DOe we not ſee the Duke?

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.l: Oh! we ſought
Your Highneſſe everie where.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this enchantment?
Where am I?

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: My Sonne.
Your Highnes is abus'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I've ſpeaken with him;
Vſe no deceit towards me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: They are truths, but he can't come forth, ſeek carefully
On everie ſide.
Oh Carlos how I feare!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven! what new prodegie is this? Iudge all
If I have reaſon to believe my ſelfe
Enchanted: I went forth the garden, thinking
To ſee before mine eyes Fabritios Ghoſt,
When ſuddenlie I fell into a precipice;
And paſſing through places which I know not,
Arriv'd heere, where to encreaſe the horrour
Of my ſad ſoule, his shadow once againe
Appear'd before me, ſpake long time unto me,
And uſ'd perſuaſions to make me ceaſe
To love Climene, and to yeild her to him.
This diſcourſe gave me much incertaintie
Of his condition; I doubted if
He was dead; but ſurpriſed and amaz'd
By this ſucceſſe, I need no more to doubt it.
Would that it plaſed Heaven he were alive,
I should be free then of that ſad remorſe
Which wounds my conſcience, I would doe him juſtice,
And banishing my fires, would ſatiſfie
My ſelfe in rendering him happy.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Sir,
It is an eaſie generoſity
To lament, an oppreſſed enemie
That is no longer to be fear'd, you think
My ſonne dead, and on that accompt, bewaile him,
But if he were alive indead, you would
Be leſſe humane.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I would not break my word.
By Heaven, by faire Climene, by all nature,
I ſweare to you Alphonſo, that if now
Fabritio yet alive should by a miracle.
Appeare before mine eyes, ſo farre would I
Be from oppoſing ſtill his juſt deſires
That I would willing lie reſigne unto him.
That Beautie ſo belou'd and Cherished.

div.head: SCENA SEPTIMA.
div.stage: Fabritio, The Duke, Alphonſo, Carlos, Climeno, Iſabella, Valorio, Guards.
Fabritio comming forth from behind the falſe wall.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Behould me living then, moſt generous Prince,
Feep your word and your oath, and make me happie.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Shake of your feare.
It is Fabritio living, and his death
Is but a feigned thing.

sp.speaker: Fabritio.
sp.l: Sir, at your feete
I humbly doe expect the bleſt effect
Of what you promiſed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'le keepe my word,
Climene's yours.

sp.speaker: Alphonſo.
sp.l: Sir, favour my poore familie
In everie point, givs Carlos too in marriage
Vnto my daughter, and approve with me
Their innocent deſires,

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: I humble crave
That favour from your Highneſſe

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I conſent to't;
Carlos, enjoy your wish, although I am
Deceived by your artifice; but loſing
My Miſtreſſe, I loſe my injuſtice too:
In not betraying me, you did betray
My glorie, who commands ill, should be ill
Obey'd', unjuſt deſignes may juſtly be
Deſtroy'd: Come follow me, and whilſt your joyes
Are making readie, rell me by what Art
The Amourous Fantaſme plaid his ſubtle part.

div.trailer: The End of the fifth and laſt Act.

sp.l: LEt me Star gaze a while, and calculate
Thoſe Heavens, to know our fortune, or our fate
Before I dare to ſpeak; I cannot ſee
One cloud appeare that should diſcourage me;
Tis a good omen: Faire Queen of this night,
Not Cynthia, but a Goddeſſe far more bright,
To you I kneel. From him, whoſe glory is
To offer you a pleaſing Sacrifice,
I meane th' ambitious Poet I am come,
Humbly to begg a favourable doome
Vpon his Fantaſme, who although he be
At the full point of his felicity
A perfect body now, yet if you frowne
Vpon his action, and ſo cry him downe,
No more a feigned Fantaſme to be made,
He dyes indead, and flyes into a shade.
